[[Image:Form696.png|thumb|350px|Form 696 from the Metropolitan Police web site]]'''Form 696''' is a [[risk assessment]] [[Form (document)|form]] which the [[London]] [[Metropolitan Police Service|Metropolitan Police]] requests [[promoter (entertainment)|promoter]]s and [[licensee]]s of events to complete and submit 14 days in advance of an event in 21 [[London boroughs]]. Non compliance with this may result in police opposition to event licences being granted.<ref name=Orlowski>{{cite web|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2008/11/11/met_police_live_music_terror_trawl/|title=Police Vet Live Music, DJs for 'terror risk': Locking Down Garage...and RnB, Basement|work=[[The Register]]|publisher=[[Situation Publishing]] Ltd ([[United Kingdom|UK]])|format=[[World Wide Web|Web]]|date=11 November 2008|accessdate=3 March 2009}}<!--According to the Wikipedia article on this publication, its reliability is dubious.--></ref> This form has become controversial due to its stipulation that names, stage names, private addresses, and phone numbers of all promoters, [[DJ]]s and [[artist]]s be listed. The form also asks for a description of the style of music to be performed and the [[target audience]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.met.police.uk/events/forms/696.doc|title=Form 696 - Promotion / Event Risk Assessment|publisher=Metropolitan Police|accessdate=21 March 2011|format=MS Word}}</ref> The original form asked for details of [[ethnic group]]s likely to attend the performance, but that version was revised to omit those parameters in December 2008.<ref name=guardian20090129>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2009/jan/21/police-form-696-garage-music|title=Are police using 'risk-assessment' form 696 to close garage clubs?|newspaper=The Guardian|date=29 January 2009|accessdate=20 February 2009}}</ref> In November 2017, the Met Police announced that following a review of how the form was being used it was to be scrapped.<ref name="BBC 10 November 2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-41946915|title=Form 696: 'Racist police form' to be scrapped in London|publisher=BBC NEWS|date=10 November 2017}}</ref>
==Opposition== [[Feargal Sharkey]], Head of [[UK Music]] and former lead singer of [[The Undertones]], gave evidence to the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] [[Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee]] in November 2008 stating that "We learned that the Metropolitan Police, in conjunction with an organization called London Councils - a representative body for all London borough - at the end of last year jointly wrote to all 33 local London boroughs recommending that they insert some particular wording into their local licensing policy statements." He added that the [[London Borough of Hillingdon]] in west London, "tries to make a direct connection not only between crime and disorder and live music, but most astonishingly - I'm still knocked over in disbelief - between live music and the prevention of terrorism."<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.hillingdon.gov.uk/media/pdf/r/6/Licensing_Policy.pdf |title= Statement of Licensing Policy|publisher = London Borough of Hillingdon |date = January 2008|accessdate = 21 February 2009 |format = PDF |pages = 7 | |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110608211242/http://www.hillingdon.gov.uk/media/pdf/r/6/Licensing_Policy.pdf |archivedate = 8 June 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003889459|title=Sharkey Warns MPs On Policing Of Concert Licensing |publisher=Billboard|date=11 November 2008|accessdate=20 February 2009}}</ref> Sharkey stated that he would be seeking a [[Judicial Review]] on the use of the form and had complained to the [[Equality and Human Rights Commission]] about the targeting of musical styles favoured by black and Asian teenagers.<ref name=independent20081121>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/how-form-696-could-pull-the-plug-on-the-capitals-music-scene-1028240.html|title=How Form 696 could pull the plug on the capital's music scene|newspaper=The Independent |date=21 November 2008|accessdate=2009-02-20}}</ref> According to Sharkey an afternoon school charity concert in a public park had been cancelled because organisers could not supply the details of the young performers.<ref name=Orlowski />
[[Jon McClure]], lead singer with [[Reverend and the Makers]], set up a petition on the [[UK]] [[Prime Minister]]'s website to allow protest against what he alleges as "racial discrimination".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clashmusic.com/news/jon-mclure-protests-form-696|title=Jon McLure Protests Form 696 - Musicians Set Up Petition|publisher=Clash Music|date=2 December 2008|accessdate=20 February 2009}}</ref>
In a statement on their web site, The British Academy of Composers and Songwriters CEO Patrick Rackow stated "...the imposition of Form 696 on live music is likely to discourage the existence and growth of live music. Music has long been a positive form of free expression, for people from all walks of life to create and enjoy. This form appears to single out certain genres of music and ethnic audiences and therefore the Academy cannot support it.”<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.britishacademy.com/public-news/metropolitan-police-form-696.html|title=Metropolitan Police Form 696|publisher=British Academy of Composers and Songwriters|accessdate=8 March 2009}}</ref>
In December 2008, Mike Howlett, Chairman of the Music Producers Guild (UK), wrote to the General Secretary of the Musicians Union "In keeping with the Musicians Union and UK Music, we feel this is a gross infringement of civil liberties and a form of racial discrimination. We also feel that this will deter the staging of live musical events, stifle free expression and possibly penalise certain genres of music and ethnic audiences. Our members are horrified that this legislation, introduced in 2006, is being enforced under the guise of public law and order. We see no reason why artists and/or venue owners and managers should be forced to comply."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mpg.org.uk/news_stories/102|title=MPG letter of Support towards MU to stop form 696|publisher=Music Producers Guild|date=12 December 2008|accessdate=8 March 2009|last=Howlett |first=Mike}} </ref>
==Police position== David Isles, Detective Superintendent of the Metropolitan Police Clubs and Vice unit has stated that Form 696 is not designed to stop people having a good time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/6music/news/20081203_form696.shtml|title=Form 696 fury|publisher=BBC 6 Music News|accessdate=2009-02-21}} </ref> The Metropolitan Police web site describes the form as a ''Promotion Event risk assessment form''.<ref> {{cite web|url=http://content.met.police.uk/Article/Organising-a-promotion-or-event/1400002385589/1400002385589|title=Metropolitan Police Service - Events |publisher=Metropolitan Police Service|accessdate=19 January 2013}}</ref>
Detective Chief Superintendent Richard Martin stated that the original form, with its questions relating to audience ethnicity "was removed just because I don't think it added any value to the form.... We take account of where the event is playing, what other events might be playing nearby, the type of music that's being played, and whether there have been problems before. We've had quite a few of what I consider 'higher risk events', where there may be some problems - so we recommend additional searching processes and additional security to help manage the event safely."<ref name=guardian20090129 /> "It's not about being risk averse, it's about managing the risk," he said. "If you're a publican and you are just having some performers to entertain your regular customers, you won't be expected to do a risk assessment. It's for when the performance is being put on to draw people in. We will never assess somebody just on the genre of music they are performing. There is a whole raft of factors that are taken into account."<ref name=independent20081121 />
==Form revised== In September 2009, the Metropolitan Police announced "that venues would no longer be asked for details of the music style. A requirement to provide the telephone number of the performing artist will also be dropped and an independent "scrutiny panel" will be set up to ensure that the form is not misused."<ref name=guardian7-9>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2009/sep/07/met-police-form-696-clubs|title=Met police bows to pressure to drop question on 'racist' form 696|newspaper=The Guardian|date=7 September 2009|accessdate=15 November 2009}}</ref> [[Feargal Sharkey]] described this as an "exercise in semantics" and called for the form to be completely scrapped. He added that "it was clear that the altered version continued to target musicians from ethnic minorities and he objected strongly to a question which asks about the 'make-up of the patrons'."<ref name=guardian7-9/>
==Form 696 scrapped== On 10 November 2017, it was announced that the use of Form 696 was to be discontinued in London following a review called for by [[Mayor of London]] [[Sadiq Khan]].<ref name="Independent 10 November 2017">{{cite web |url= https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/form-696-scrapped-racist-police-paperwork-claims-london-mcs-djs-grime-garage-a8048821.html|title= Form 696: Police scrap 'racist' risk assessment for MCs and DJs| last= Nerssessian| first= Joe |date= 10 November 2017|website= www.independent.co.uk |publisher= [[The Independent]] | accessdate= 10 November 2017 }}</ref><ref name="BBC 10 November 2017"/> Reporting the decision, the BBC noted, "The Met denied the form had been used to target particular genres but said it had decided to drop it after a fall in 'serious incidents' at music events"; however, the BBC also reported that a [[Freedom of Information Act 2000|Freedom of Information]] request earlier in 2017 had discovered that 16 other English police forces were using forms similar to Form 696.<ref name="BBC 10 November 2017"/>
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *[https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm200708/cmselect/cmcumeds/memo/licensing/meli6802.htm Supplementary Memorandum] from Feargal Sharkey, CEO, UK Music to Culture, Media and Sport committee *[http://content.met.police.uk/cs/Satellite?blobcol=urldata&blobheadername1=Content-Type&blobheadername2=Content-Disposition&blobheadervalue1=application%2Fmsword&blobheadervalue2=inline%3B+filename%3D%22665%2F669%2F696_2016.doc%22&blobkey=id&blobtable=MungoBlobs&blobwhere=1284063074733&ssbinary=true MS Word version of form] at the Metropolitan Police

'''Giuseppe Di Giacomo''' (born 1 January 1945 in [[Avola]], [[Italy]]) is an Italian [[philosopher]] and essayist. [[File:Giuseppe Di Giacomo.jpg|thumb|Giuseppe Di Giacomo]]
Author of about a hundred scientific publications on the relationship between aesthetics and literature,<ref>His most important work on the relationship between aesthetics and literature is ''Estetica e letteratura. Il grande romanzo tra Ottocento e Novecento'', Laterza, 1999, rpt. 2010; Spanish translation, Valencia, 2013</ref> as well as on the relationship between aesthetics and the visual arts, with an emphasis on modern and contemporary culture, and on topics such as the image, representation, the art/life nexus, memory and the notion of testimony.
==Biography== Before undertaking his university career, immediately after graduating in Philosophy (with professor Emilio Garroni), Di Giacomo taught in senior high schools and, even before that, while still a university student, he was a substitute teacher for several months in various junior high schools. In 1976, he was awarded a contract to teach Epistemology at the Faculty of Natural, mathematical and physical sciences of the University of Parma, and obtained a permanent position in the same university two years later. On 28 February 1987 he became a researcher at ''Sapienza'' University of Rome, where, starting from 19 October 1993, he became Associate Professor and, from 1 November 2001, Full Professor of Aesthetics. Since November 2012, he has been the Director of MLAC (Museo Laboratorio di Arte Contemporanea/Laboratory Museum of Contemporary Art), ''Sapienza'' University. He is a member of the Teaching Staff of the Ph.D. in Philosophy of the same university, where he also served, for six years, as President of the Master’s Degree of the former Faculty of Philosophy. He has coordinated national research projects (Progetti PRIN) and has taken part in international research projects. Over the last decade, he has coordinated university researches (Ricerche di Ateneo) involving more than thirty scholars from different study areas and focussing on aesthetic-philosophical and literary-artistic topics.
He edited, with Claudio Zambianchi, the anthology ''Alle origini dell'opera d'arte contemporanea'' (Roma-Bari, Laterza, 2008; 4th ed. 2012)
He is a founding member of SIE (''Società Italiana di Estetica/Italian Society of Aesthetics'').
He is the editor of the book series ''Figure dell'estetica'' of the publishing house Alboversorio (Milan).
He is a member of the scientific board of the following journals * Paradigmi * Studi di estetica * Rivista di estetica * Estetica. Studi e ricerche * Comprendre. Revista catalana de filosofia
Di Giacomo is also a member of the scientific board of ''Aesthetica Preprint'', a book series of the ''Centro Internazionale Studi di Estetica'' (''International Centre for the Study of Aesthetics'').
== Thought== Di Giacomo maintains that, in order to tackle the issue of the image today, it is necessary to refuse both an interpretation of the image as a mere mirror of things and its interpretation as an exclusively self-referential system of signs. Based on his reading of Wittgenstein, he draws the conclusion that logical representation entails something that manifests itself and, while doing so, remains ‘other’, distinct from the visibility of the representation itself.<ref>Cf. ''Dalla logica all'estetica'', pp. 97-147</ref> Thus, in presenting itself, the image manifests the other of the visible, of the representable: that other which reveals itself in the visible, by hiding from it. And this is precisely how the image becomes an icon of the invisible.
However, starting from Adorno’s reflection, the image tends to lose its figurative character but, at the same time, it continues to exist;<ref>Cf. ''Alle origini dell'opera d'arte contemporanea'', pp. 203-222</ref> the image is, indeed, both a thing and a non-thing: a paradoxical “real unreality”. This ensues from the attempt to divide the double-edged nature of the image into its constituent elements: on the one hand, a readymade in which the representational dimension melts into a purely presentational dimension, and, on the other hand, a solely mental image endowed with a weak material support.<ref>Cf. ''Astrazione e astrazioni'', pp. 11-19</ref>
Today, the images of the new media are images of images and, in this sense, they are not even proper images but simulations, “simulacra”. It is no coincidence that digital images, as reproductions, have a low value as images, because they tend to acquire the aspect of something, thus losing that connection between transparency and opacity which characterises authentic images. Hence, indeed, the question whether new media are able to create real images. More particularly, it is in the kind of art that Adorno defines as “modern” that we find an overcoming of the epiphanic dimension that distinguishes the icon, where the visible is the place of manifestation of the invisible as Absolute.<ref>Cf. "La questione dell'aura tra Benjamin e Adorno", Rivista di Estetica, 52 (1/20013), p. 245</ref> As we have become aware of the impossibility to exhaust the whole of reality and, at the same time, to manifest the Absolute, what emerges now is a conception of the image as something that can be interrogated as a testimony of what does not allow itself to be translated into an image: to testify is indeed to tell what cannot be told completely. In this sense, testimony coincides not with memory, as consistent with what happened, but with the immemorial, which refers to something we can neither remember nor forget completely, that is something that is neither totally speakable nor totally unspeakable.<ref>Cf. ''Volti della memoria'', pp. 445-481</ref>
In short, a witness only speaks starting from the impossibility to speak. That the image is equivalent to testimony means, then, that the attempt to say the unsayable is an infinite task, and this is why the question of the image forms an integral part of the ethical question. This entails that in the image there is no completeness and, consequently, neither redemption nor reconciliation with the real. From this point of view, to consider the image as testimony is tantamount to seeing it as the place of a perpetually unresolved tension between memory and oblivion, thus as the expression of the imperative of sense in a context, such as the contemporary one, in which both world and art seem to be increasingly abandoned to non-sense.

{{unreferenced|date=August 2010}} {{Infobox book | name = In Search of The La's: A Secret Liverpool | image = In Search of The La's - A Secret Liverpool cover.jpg | caption = | author = M.W. Macefield | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = | series = | subject = | genre = | publisher = Helter Skelter | pub_date = December 11, 2003 | media_type = Print ([[Paperback]]) | pages = 192 | isbn = 1-900924-63-3 | oclc = 238641847 | dewey = | congress = }} '''''In Search of The La's: A Secret Liverpool''''' is a biography about [[The La's]] written by M.W. Macefield, published in 2003 by Helter Skelter Publishing. The book gives a detailed history of the band with interviews from several ex-members and other persons related to the group. The author also discusses his own journey in tracking down each of the interviewees. ==Synopsis==
"With the timeless single "[[There She Goes (The La's song)|There She Goes]]", Lee Mavers' La's overtook [[The Stone Roses]] as great British guitar hopes and paved the way for the [[Britpop]] renaissance of [[Blur (band)|Blur]] and [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]]. However, since 1991, The La's have been silent, while rumors of studio-perfectionism, madness and drug addiction have abounded with Mavers lined up as another rock casualty. The author sets out to discover the truth behind Mavers' lost decade and eventually gains a revelatory audience with Mavers himself."
The author, MW Macefield, travels to [[Liverpool]] to interview several ex-members of the band (including co-founder [[Mike Badger]], guitarist [[Paul Hemmings]] and bass player [[John Power (singer-songwriter)|John Power]]), and sundry other personnel, and eventually gets to chat with the group's chief songwriter [[Lee Mavers]]. In it several La's myths are dispelled along the way, new song titles are named, and the past and future of the band is discussed. ==Reception== {{Empty section|date=August 2010}} ==Release details== * United Kingdom (December 11, 2003) Helter Skelter Publishing. Paperback edition ({{ISBN|1-900924-63-3}}) * Revised edition 2012 {{ISBN|9781905139316}} {{ISBN|1905139314}} ==See also== * [[The La's]] * [[Lee Mavers]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Expand section|date=August 2010}} {{The La's}} {{DEFAULTSORT:In Search Of The La's: A Secret Liverpool}} [[Category:Books about rock musicians]] [[Category:Debut books]] [[Category:English non-fiction books]] [[Category:2003 books]] {{music-publication-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2015}} {{Infobox artist | name = Jonty Hurwitz | image = Jonty Hurwitz.jpg | caption = Jonty Hurwitz | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1969|9|2|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]] | nationality = South African | website = {{url|www.jonty.art}} | field = [[Sculpture]] and Financial Technology | training = [[University of the Witwatersrand]]
[[University of Cape Town]] }} '''Jonty Hurwitz''' (born 2 September 1969 in Johannesburg) is an artist, [[engineer]] and entrepreneur. Hurwitz creates scientifically inspired artworks and [[Anamorphosis|anamorphic]] sculptures.[http://www.arte.tv/guide/fr/048913-007/tracks#details-description Tracks: Jonty Hurwitz], on [[Arte|ARTE]] 29 June 2013. He is recognised for the smallest human form ever created using [[nano technology]].{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/11/14/sculpture-human-sperm_n_6158258.html |title=Artist Creates Sculptures So Tiny They Can't Be Seen By The Human Eye |publisher=Huffington Post, Leigh Weingus |date= 14 November 2014}} ==Early life== Jonty Hurwitz was born in Johannesburg, South Africa, to Selwin, a hotelier and entrepreneur and Marcia Berger, a drama lecturer and teacher. Jonty spent his early life living in small hotels in rural towns in South Africa while his father built up his business. Jonty studied [[Electrical Engineering]] at the [[University of the Witwatersrand]] in [[Johannesburg]] from 1989 to 1993. His major was [[Signal Processing]]. He then joined the [[University of Cape Town]] Remote Sensing Group as a full-time researcher under Professor Michael Inggs, publishing a paper on radar pattern recognition.{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/login.jsp?tp=&arnumber=365844 |title=Synthetic Range Profile Measurements of Aircraft, COMSIG-93, COMSIG ’93:204 – 209, September 1993. M R Inggs, J.B. Hurwitz, and A. Langman. |publisher=COMSIG |date=1993}} Following his research post, Hurwitz traveled for a long period of time in India studying Yoga and wood carving. ==Career in art== In a 2015, documentary by CNN International on Hurwitz's artwork,{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/videos/tv/2015/03/13/spc-ones-to-watch-sculpture-c.cnn |title=Is this the World's Smallest Sculpture? |publisher=CNN |date= March 2015}} [[BBC Radio 2]] art critic Estelle Lovatt commented on Hurwitz's work: "If [[Leonardo Da Vinci]] were alive today, he would have been doing what Jonty is doing. He would have been using algorithms. No one else works like him today. His art is the mix between the emotional and the intelligent, and that's what gives it that spark."{{cite book|author=Mathematics of Self|title=Art of Jonty Hurwitz|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=leATtAEACAAJ|date=8 January 2018|publisher=Blurb, Incorporated|isbn=978-1-389-03122-9|page=1}} Hurwitz's work focuses on the aesthetics of art in the context of human perception. His early body of sculpture was discovered by Estelle Lovatt during 2011 in an article for ''Art of England Magazine'': "Thinning the divide gap between art and science, Hurwitz is cognisant of the two being holistically co-joined in the same way as we are naturally, comfortably split between our spiritual and operational self".{{cite web|url=http://static1.squarespace.com/static/541afcd4e4b09246971aad4b/t/5421b307e4b0004bfbd4f10e/1411494663328/ARTofEnglandJonty.pdf |title=Art of England, Estelle Lovatt, Feb 2011 publication, p50. |publisher=Art of England |date= Feb 2011}}[http://www.pocketmags.com/viewmagazine.aspx?catid=1029&category=Art+%26+Photography&subcatid=183&subcategory=Art&title=Art+of+England&titleid=1015&issueid=31285 Art of England Magazine] Hurwitz began producing sculptures in 2008. In 2009, his first sculpture '[[Yoda]] and the Anamorph' won the People’s Choice Bentliff Prize of the [[Maidstone Museum and Art Gallery]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kentonline.co.uk/kent/news/winner-of-art-prize-announced-a105202/|title=Winner of Art Prize Announced. |publisher=Kent Online | date= 6 February 2009}} Later in 2009 he won the [[Bernard Noble|Noble]] Sculpture Prize{{cite web|url=http://www.bnsf.org.uk/winners/2009/ |title=Bernard Noble Sculpture Prize. |date= Feb 2011}} and was commissioned to install his first large scale work (a nude study of his father called 'Dietro di me')[http://www.jontyhurwitz.com/noble-prize ''Dietro di me''] by Jonty Hurwitz in the Italian village [[Colletta di Castelbianco]]. In 2010, he was selected as a finalist for the 4th International [[Arte Laguna Prize]] in Venice, Italy.{{cite web|url=http://www.premioartelaguna.it/catalogo/4edizione/catalogo_premio_arte_laguna_2009.pdf |title=Arte Laguna Exhibition Catalogue, p106. |publisher=Arte Laguna Prize |date= 2010}} In January 2013, Hurwitz's anamorphic work was described by the art blogger [[Colossal (blog)|Christopher Jobson]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thisiscolossal.com/2013/01/the-skewed-anamorphic-sculptures-and-engineered-illusions-of-jonty-hurwitz/ |title=The skewed anamorphic sculptures and engineered illusions of Jonty Hurwitz |publisher=Christopher Jobson, Colossal |date= 21 January 2013}} In a short documentary about Hurwitz's "Generation Pi" philosophy by ''Vera Productions'' it is estimated that the sculpture received 20 million views online in the space of a few weeks.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KcTp5Q3-8Ng |title=The Paintbrush of Mathematics |publisher=Vera Productions |date= March 2013}} In early 2013 Hurwitz was introduced to the [[Savoy Hotel]] by London art agent Sally Vaughan. Hurwitz was commissioned to be [[Artist in Residence]] at the hotel{{cite web|url=http://www.artlyst.com/articles/londons-savoy-hotel-continues-its-artist-in-residence-tradition |title=London's Savoy Hotel continues its artist in residence tradition |publisher=Artlyst |date= April 2013}} and produce a sculpture of the hotel’s historically iconic [[Mascot]] ''Kaspar the Cat''.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/a-homage-to-kaspar-the-friendly-cat-checks-in-at-the-savoys-new-eatery-8600305.html |title=A homage to Kaspar the friendly Cat checks in at the Savoy's new eatery |publisher=The Independent |date= April 2013}} Hurwitz lived for several months in the hotel producing the sculpture. In the same year, Hurwitz was also nominated for the [[Threadneedle Prize]] and exhibited a collection at the [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]] in London. By late 2013, in a special edition of Art of England on portraiture, Hurwitz was cited as the #1 portrait artist in the UK.{{cite web|url=http://www.pocketmags.com/viewmagazine.aspx?catid=1029&category=Art+%26+Photography&subcatid=183&subcategory=Art&title=Art+of+England&titleid=1015&issueid=60975 |title=Six of the Best, Sally Vaughan, Aug 2013. |publisher=Art of England |date= Aug 2013}} In January 2014 Hurwitz was voted #46 in the top 100 artists of 2013 by the American art site, Empty Kingdom.{{cite web|url=http://www.emptykingdom.com/featured/empty-kingdom-top-100-artists-of-2013/ |title=Top 100 artists of 2013, Empty Kingdom. |publisher=Empty Kingdom |date= 31 January 2014}} In the same month, Hurwitz's anamorphic work was blogged as "The best of 2013" by the American Art and Culture magazine, [[Juxtapoz]].{{cite web|url=http://www.juxtapoz.com/current/sculptures-by-jonty-hurwitz |title=Best of 2013: Sculpture by Jonty Hurwitz |publisher=Juxtapoz |date= 31 December 2013}} In 2013 Hurwitz's work was also curated by ''Science Gallery International'' for a touring group show entitled ‘Illusion’ curated by [[Trinity College Dublin]].[http://www.international.sciencegallery.com/illusion/ Science Gallery International] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150212190314/http://www.international.sciencegallery.com/illusion/ |date=12 February 2015 }} The show presents a collection of installation artworks from around the world that affect human perception. The exhibition led to a 2014/2015 tour in the USA{{cite web|url=http://www.utsandiego.com/news/2014/may/30/fleet-science-center-illusion-exhibit/ |title=Real fun at Fleet’s ‘Illusion’ exhibit |publisher=U-T San Diego, Karla Peterson |date= 30 May 2014}} where it attracted over 170,000 visitors.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessandleadership.com/marketing/item/48935-science-gallery-dublin-hono |title=Science Gallery Dublin honoured with dedicated 68c stamp |publisher=Business & Leadership Magazine |date=7 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150110010448/http://www.businessandleadership.com/marketing/item/48935-science-gallery-dublin-hono |archivedate=10 January 2015 |df=dmy-all }} The show then moved on to Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia in 2015 and Leipzig, Germany in 2016. In late 2014, he released a series of “nano sculptures” under the title of ″Trust″. This series of works captured the attentions of both the scientific and art community, being cited by among others, [[Nature (journal)|Nature]],{{cite web|url=http://www.nature.com/news/images-of-the-month-november-2014-1.16481 |title=Image of the Month: November 2014 |publisher=Nature Journal, Daniel Cressey |date= 5 December 2014}} [[Scientific American]],{{cite web|url=http://blogs.scientificamerican.com/cocktail-party-physics/2014/12/20/physics-week-in-review-december-20-2014/ |title=Physics Week in Review |publisher=Scientific American, Jennifer Ouellette |date= 20 December 2014}} [[Popular Science]] and [[Phys.org]].{{cite web|url=http://phys.org/news/2014-11-science-art-nanosculpture-marvels.html |title=When science and art produce nanosculpture marvels |publisher=Phys.org, Nancy Owano |date= 18 November 2014}} In 2015, Hurwitz was elected a member of the [[Royal British Society of Sculptors]]. In 2016 the [[Royal Photographic Society]] selected a [[Scanning Electron Microscope]] photograph by Hurwitz and Stefan Diller as one of the top 100 'Royal Society International Images for Science'.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-3777603/From-droplets-spider-web-spiral-galaxy-Stunning-photos-reveal-natural-beauty-science.html#ixzz4JfHIgjum |title=From droplets on a spider web to a spiral galaxy: Stunning photos reveal the natural beauty in science |publisher=Daily Mail, Libby Plumner |date= 7 September 2016}} ===Anamorphic sculpture=== Hurwitz has produced a body of work using both [[oblique projection|oblique]] (perspective) and [[catoptric]] (mirror) [[anamorphosis]]. In an interview with Christopher Jobson, Hurwitz explains his anamorphic inspiration as follows: “I have always been torn between art and physics. In a moment of self-doubt in 2008, I wandered into the [[National Portrait Gallery (United States)|National Portrait Gallery]] and stumbled across a strange anamorphic piece by [[William Scrots]], a portrait of Edward VI from 1546. Followed shortly down the aisle by The Ambassadors by [[Hans Holbein the Younger|Hans Holbein]] from 1533. My life changed forever. I rushed home and within hours was devouring the works of [[M. C. Escher]], [[Leonardo Da Vinci|Da Vinci]] and many more. In a breath I had found “brothers” in a smallish group of artists spanning 500 years with exactly the same dilemma as me. Within two months I was deep in production of my first work. My art rests on the shoulders of giants, and I am grateful to them.”{{cite web|url=http://twistedsifter.com/2013/04/anamorphic-sculptures-made-with-algorithms-jonty-hurwitz/ |title=Anamorphic Sculptures Made With Algorithms |publisher=Twisted Sifter |date= 17 April 2013}} [[Anamorphosis]] as a form of art has a long history. A page in Leonardo Da Vinci’s note book (folio 35 verso a of the [[Codex Atlanticus]]) shows two strangely elongated sketches of a child's head and an eye. These distorted and hesitant drawings, the first known anamorphoses, from around 1485”.{{cite web|url=http://startstudioarts.si.edu/2009/08/anamorphoses-in-the-eye-of-leonardo.html |title=Anamorphoses in the eyes of Leonardo |publisher=The Smithsonian, Holly Sloofman |date= 26 August 2009}} In the mid-18th Century anamorphosis was also used by [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] artists to secretly depict images of [[Bonnie Prince Charlie]] in the wake of brutal English censorship.{{cite web|url=http://www.core77.com/blog/fine_art/how_to_hide_a_forbidden_image_in_plain_sight_anamorphic_cylinders_27356.asp |title=How to Hide a Forbidden Image in Plain Sight |publisher=Core77, Rain Noe |date= 22 July 2014}} Hurwitz is a pioneer in creating [[catoptric]] sculpture.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} Until the creation of his first work ''Rejuvenation'', anamorphic sculptures have not been known to have existed in art history. In his online talks, Hurwitz explains that this is a function of processing power and that whilst painting is possible in a mirror, three dimensional anamorphosis could only have come into being with the advent of powerful computers. Each of his sculptures involves billions of calculations{{cite web|url=http://www.ignant.de/2013/01/30/anamorphic-sculptures/ |title=Anamorphic Sculptures |publisher=Ignant |date= 13 January 2013}} using an [[algorithm]] derived from the mathematical constant [[π]].{{cite web|url= http://www.designboom.com/art/anamorphic-sculptures-by-jonty-hurwitz/ |title=Anamorphic sculptures by Jonty Hurwitz |publisher=Design Boom |date= 21 January 2013}}{{cite web|url= http://www.urbanghostsmedia.com/2013/02/kiss-of-chytrid-anamorphic-art-jonty-hurwitz/ |title=Kiss of Chytrid: Anamorphic art by Jonty Hurwitz |publisher=Urban Ghost Media |date= 5 February 2013}} Hurwitz asserts that his art is “contemporary to the millisecond”.{{cite web|url=http://nsfwyoutube.com/videos/398405/Jonty-Hurwitz-talk-Contemporary-Art-is-measured-in-milliseconds |title=Contemporary Art is Measured in Milliseconds |publisher=NSFW Youtube, Vera Productions, Jonty Hurwitz |date= March 2013}} [[Kinetic Art]] curator and director of the London ''Kinetica Museum'', Dianne Harris, described Hurwitz's art as follows "The works of polymath Jonty Hurwitz are contemporary [[trompe l'oeil]], at first glance appearing abstract, but in mirrored reflections, representational".{{cite web|url=http://www.kinetica-artfair.com/?exhibitors/2013/jonty-hurwitz |title=Kinetica Museum Artist Profile, 2013. |publisher=Kinetica |date= 2013}} ===Nano sculpture=== In 2014, Hurwitz pioneered a new sculptural technique{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} in the field of [[Nanoart]] using [[multiphoton lithography]]{{cite web|url=http://cen.chempics.org/post/105392403108/trust-artist-jonty-hurwitz-and-nanoscientist |title=Trust |publisher=Chemical and Engineering News |date= 16 December 2014}} and [[photogrammetry]]{{cite web|url=http://all3dp.com/enter-photo-studios-21st-century/?hvid=3766p |title=Enter the Photo Studios of the 21st Century |publisher=All3DP |date= 29 December 2014}} to create the world’s smallest human portraits of his first love. The works of art were inspired by the nineteenth century marble sculpture of Cupid and Psyche by [[Antonio Canova]], part of the permanent collection of the [[Louvre Museum]], Paris. Hurwitz’s works are so tiny that they are invisible to the human eye, able to be placed on the forehead of an ant. Smaller details of the works are at approximately the 300 [[nanometer]] scale, similar to the [[wavelengths]] of visible light and are therefore near impossible by the laws of physics to see in the visible spectrum. The only way to observe these works is through a non-optical method of magnification like a [[scanning electron microscope]]. To create these works Hurwitz collaborated with a team of over 20 people, including Stephan Hengsbach of the [[Karlsruhe Institute of Technology]] and Yehiam Prior of the [[Weizmann Institute of Science]], an art project centred in the world of academic [[physics]]. In February 2015, Hurwitz's sculpture "Trust" was awarded the world record for the "Smallest sculpture of a human" by the [[Guinness Book of Records]].{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/products/books/superlatives/smallest |title=Sculpture of a human 80 x 100 x 30 micrometers |publisher=Guinness World Records |date= 13 Feb 2015}} In an interview with Beautiful/Decay Hurwitz explains the philosophy behind the works: “As technology starts to evolve faster than our human perception is able to handle, the line between science and myth becomes blurred. We live in an era where the impossible has finally come to pass. In our own little way we have become demigods of creation in our physical world…. The nano works that I present to you here represent more that just a feat of science though. They represent the moment in history that we ourselves are able to create a full human form at the same scale as the sperm that creates us in order to facilitate the creation.”{{cite web|url=http://beautifuldecay.com/2014/11/12/jonty-hurwitzs-sculptures-small-cant-seen-human-eye/ |title=Jonty Hurwitz’s sculptures are so small the can’t be seen with the human eye |publisher=Beautiful/Decay |date= 12 November 2014}} In an online interview with [[Slashdot]], Hurwitz himself asks the question “How can something you can't see be art?”{{cite web|url=http://tech-beta.slashdot.org/story/14/12/15/1357213/interviews-ask-jonty-hurwitz-about-art-and-engineering |title=Ask Jonty Hurwitz about Art and Engineering |publisher=Slashdot |date= January 2015}} By basing his work on the myth of [[Cupid and Psyche]] he also suggests that our belief in modern science isn't that different from the faith the ancient greeks had in the [[demigod]]s.{{cite web|url=http://thecreatorsproject.vice.com/blog/elegant-nanosculptures-fit-comfortably-inside-the-eye-of-a-needle |title=Elegant Nano Sculptures Fit Comfortably Inside the Eye of a Needle |publisher=The Creators Project, Beckett Mufson |date= 13 November 2014}} The final irony was that the sculptures were destroyed by a touch one week before the images were published on the Internet.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2836676/Is-smallest-sculpture-Nano-artist-creates-images-nude-model-easily-fit-eye-needle.html |title=Artist spends ten months creating sculptures which are half the width of a human hair... only for his friend to accidentally crush them a few minutes later |publisher=Daily Mail, Stephanie Linning |date= December 2014}} ==Career in technology== In the mid-90s, Hurwitz arrived in London following his travels in India and got his first job researching financial [[data visualization]] for [[Gilbert de Botton]], Chairman and Founder of [[GAM (company)|Global Asset Management]] (GAM). During this period, he was exposed to de Botton’s [[open architecture]] model of asset management. It was Jonty’s close relationship with de Botton, also a major British art collector, that exposed him to the art world. The two maintained a close friendship until de Botton's death in 2000. Hurwitz left Global Asset Management after two years forming his own company, ''Delve'', to develop the [[Research and Development|R&D]] in [[data visualisation]] and reporting. Jonty’s main client became de Botton himself. In 1996, GAM launched its financial reporting technology built by Hurwitz, which attracted attention in the financial media, winning several awards.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} Hurwitz’s newly formed graphics and software team evolved over several years publishing several visualization projects (non-exhaustive list): *1997 News International visual archives on the [[Cold War]] and the [[Industrial Revolution]], Published by News International *1998 [[Biosys]] an environmental simulation published by ''Take 2 Interactive''. *1998 Hurwitz was selected by the British Foreign Office to build a 3D engine called “Oceans of Innovation” to represent the leading edge of British Innovation. The work was nominated for a [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] Award.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/189832.stm | title=Bafta plugs into interactive awards. | publisher=BBC |date= 9 October 1998}} Over the years from 2000 to 2005, Hurwitz signed up a large base of asset managers for his reporting and analysis technology. In 2005, Hurwitz’s company ''Delve'' was acquired by [[Alternative Investment Market]] listed company Statpro Group PLC (SOG).{{cite web|url=http://www.proactiveinvestors.co.uk/companies/rns/050704sog4008o |title=Acquisition of Delve, a leading supplier of enterprise and web reporting. |publisher=Proactive Investors |date= 4 July 2005}} Hurwitz joined Statpro as [[Creative Director]] where he designed the first [[cloud-based|Cloud Computing]] analytics and [[risk]] platform for asset data. In 2008, Statpro launched its flagship product ''Statpro Revolution'' which was the result of this R&D. By 2014, eight out of the top ten largest asset managers in the world were Statpro Clients.{{cite web|url=http://www.statpro.com/news/eight-top-ten-largest-asset-managers-world-statpro-clients/ |title=Eight out of the top ten largest asset managers in the world Statpro Clients. |publisher=Statpro |date= 20 October 2014}} Hurwitz was co-founding Chief Technology Officer of [[Wonga.com]] in 2007 where he designed and built the first real-time online consumer loan system in the world.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} During this period, Wonga’s technology won several awards (listed below). By 2011, Wonga had begun to attract criticism and Hurwitz, as the inventor of the technology, found himself with not enough influence to guide the now large company's use of his designs. After several attempts at changing Wonga's strategy, he resigned from his operational role in November 2011, quietly releasing his sculpture entitled ''Co-Founder''. Hurwitz's technology is credited with several innovations in the financial services industry: *Financial sliders. A [[User Interface]] innovation which allowed customers to easily to get a real-time quote on the exact cost of a loan in pound and pennies.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2011/oct/16/wonga-algorithm-lending-debt-data |title=Your prosperity could depend on an Algorithm |publisher=Will Sawney,Guardian |date= 16 October 2011}} This method of communicating loan information to consumers has been adopted by several of the major high street UK lenders. These include (non-exhaustive list): [[HSBC]], [[Royal Bank of Scotland]], [[Barclays]], [[Halifax (bank)|Halifax]], [[Lloyd's of London|Lloyds]], [[Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company|Nationwide]], [[Santander Bank]], [[The Co-operative Bank|Co-operative Bank]], [[Natwest]] and [[Bank of Scotland]]. *Real-time risk technology. Wonga’s risk engine was the first ever to evaluate the credit worthiness of a customer in near real time on the internet based on the collection of data from alternative sources in combination with traditional credit scores.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} The consumer risk technology{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/parmyolson/2011/03/15/the-algorithm-that-beats-your-bank-manager/ |title=The algorithm that beats your bank manager |publisher=Parmy Olson, Forbes |date= 15 March 2011}} provided the ability to transfer money to customers within 12 minutes on the basis of the decision. Hurwitz continues to commit much of his time to [[Financial technology|fintech]] startups while at the same time building up his body of artwork. In late 2011 Hurwitz backed Damian Kimmelman, to build a next-generation data provider [[Duedil]].{{cite web|url=http://www.growthbusiness.co.uk/news-and-market-deals/fundraising-deals/1679298/duedil-secures-funding-from-wongas-jonty-hurwitz.thtml |title=Duedil secures funding from Jonty Hurwitz |publisher=Growth Business, Thomas Hobbs |date= 14 December 2011}} Duedil has since been dubbed "The Bloomberg of private companies" and has emerged as one of the key data providers in Europe and the UK.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/cd830afa-8364-11e3-86c9-00144feab7de.html#axzz3QWzwSOhb |title=UK startup dubbed 'Bloomberg of private companies' raises $17m |publisher=Financial Times, Jonathan Moules |date= 3 March 2014}} In 2011, Hurwitz [[seed money|seed funded]] the financial technology startup ''behalf.com''.{{cite web|url=https://dealbook.nytimes.com/2015/01/07/challenged-by-upstarts-lenders-try-new-strategy-cooperation/?_r=1&action=Click&contentCollection=Investment%20Banking&module=BlogPost-Title&pgtype=Blogs®ion=Body&version=Blog%20Main |title= Challenged by Upstarts, Lenders try a New Strategy: Cooperation |publisher=New York Times, Randall Smith |date= 7 January 2015}} In 2012, Hurwitz backed the UK startup bank for young people: ''Meet Osper''. ==Publications== ===Academic publications=== *''A simplified procedure for anamorphic sculpture'', 2015. Ayoub, Manal Helal. International Design Journal, Volume 5, Issue 2, pp 317–326.http://www.journal.faa-design.com/pdf/5-2-manal.pdf *''Art on the Nanoscale and Beyond: Advanced Materials'', 2016. {{Redirect|Keep Calm|the novel|Keep Calm (novel)}} {{about|the poster|the Stereophonics album|Keep Calm and Carry On (album)|the TV series episode|Keep Calm and Carry On (Supernatural)}} {{italic title}} {{EngvarB|date=November 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2018}}
<!-- This has been replaced by the SVG poster before. Please don't replace this without a discussion on the "talk" page. --> [[File:Keep-calm-and-carry-on-scan.jpg|thumb|The original 1939 ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' poster]]
'''''Keep Calm and Carry On''''' is a [[motivational poster]] produced by the [[Government of the United Kingdom|British government]] in 1939 in preparation for [[World War II]]. The poster was intended to raise the [[morale]] of the British public, threatened with widely predicted mass air attacks on major cities.<ref>{{cite book |first=Richard |last=Slocombe |title=British Posters of the Second World War |location=London |publisher=Imperial War Museum |year=2010 |isbn=9781904897927 |page=6 }}</ref><ref name="PhD">{{cite web |url=http://ww2poster.co.uk/2009/04/1939-3-posters/ |title=1939: The Three Posters (PhD Extract) |first=Rebecca, PhD |last=Lewis |work=Keep Calm and Carry on and other Second World War Posters: British Home Front Propaganda Posters of the Second World War |date=5 April 2009}}</ref> Although 2.45 million copies were printed, and although [[the Blitz]] did in fact take place, the poster was hardly ever publicly displayed and was little known until a copy was rediscovered in 2000 at [[Barter Books]], a bookshop in [[Alnwick]]. It has since been re-issued by a number of private companies, and has been used as the decorative theme for a range of products.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/magazine/7869458.stm|title=The Greatest Motivational Poster Ever?|work=''BBC News''|date= 4 February 2009|first=Stuart|last=Hughes}}</ref>
Evocative of the Victorian belief in British stoicism – the "[[stiff upper lip]]", self-discipline, fortitude, and remaining calm in adversity – the poster has become recognised around the world.<ref>{{cite news|title=Keep calm and carry on … bidding for rare poster|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2016/jun/25/wartime-poster-secret-auction|work=The Guardian|date=2 October 2016}}</ref> It was thought that only two original copies survived until a collection of approximately 15 was brought in to the ''[[Antiques Roadshow]]'' in 2012 by the daughter of an ex-[[Royal Observer Corps]] member.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2105518/Keep-calm-carry-Only-surviving-stash-original-iconic-poster-appears-Antiques-Roadshow.html|accessdate=13 May 2012|location=London|work=Daily Mail|first=Chris|last=Slack|title=Keep Calm and Carry On... to the bank: Original wartime poster shows up on Antiques Roadshow|date=23 February 2012}}</ref> A few further examples have come to light since.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 63.</ref>
==History==
===Design and production=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = horizontal | header = | header_align = | header_background = pink | footer = | footer_align = | footer_background = pink | width = 129
| image1 = Freedomisinperilposter.jpg | width1 = 130 | alt1 = | caption1 = "Freedom Is in Peril" (reconstruction)
| image2 = Your Courage, Your Cheerfulness, Your Resolution Will Bring Us Victory.svg | width2 = 130 | alt2 = | caption2 = "Your Courage" (reconstruction) }} The ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' poster was designed by the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] during the period of 27 June to 6 July 1939.<ref name="irving">{{cite web |url= https://history.blog.gov.uk/2014/06/27/keep-calm-and-carry-on-the-compromise-behind-the-slogan/ |title=Keep Calm and Carry On – The Compromise Behind the Slogan |first=Henry |last=Irving |publisher= History of Government Blog |date= 27 June 2014 |accessdate= 27 June 2014}}</ref> It was produced as part of a series of three "Home Publicity" posters (the others read "<u>Your</u> ''Courage,'' <u>Your</u> ''Cheerfulness,'' <u>Your</u> ''Resolution Will Bring Us Victory''" and "''Freedom Is in Peril / Defend It With All Your Might''"). Each poster showed the slogan under a representation of a "[[Tudor Crown (heraldry)|Tudor Crown]]" (a symbol of the state). They were intended to be distributed to strengthen morale in the event of a wartime disaster, such as mass bombing of major cities using high explosives and poison gas, which was widely expected within hours of an outbreak of war.<ref name="PhD"/>
A career civil servant named A. P. Waterfield came up with "Your Courage" as "a rallying war-cry that will bring out the best in everyone of us and put us in an offensive mood at once".<ref name="PhD"/><ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 45–6.</ref> Others involved in the planning of the early posters included: [[John Hilton (industrial relations)|John Hilton]], [[Montague Burton Professor of Industrial Relations|Professor of Industrial Relations]] at [[Cambridge University]], responsible overall as Director of Home Publicity; William Surrey Dane, managing director at [[Odhams Press]]; [[Gervas Huxley]], former head of publicity for the [[Empire Marketing Board]]; William Codling, controller of [[HMSO]]; [[Harold Nicolson]], MP; W. G. V. Vaughan, who became Director of the General Production Division (GPD); H. V. Rhodes, who later wrote an occasional paper on setting up a new government department; [[Ivison Macadam]]; "Mr Cruthley"; and "Mr Francis". [[Ernest Wallcousins]] was the artist tasked with creating the poster designs.<ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 42, 44, 47.</ref>
Detailed planning for the posters had started in April 1939 and the eventual designs were prepared after meetings between officials from the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] and [[HM Treasury]] on 26 June 1939 and between officials from the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] and [[HMSO]] on 27 June 1939.<ref name="irving"/> Roughs of the poster were completed on 6 July 1939, and the final designs were agreed by the Home Secretary [[Samuel Hoare, 1st Viscount Templewood]] on 4 August 1939. Printing began on 23 August 1939, the day that Nazi Germany and the USSR signed the [[Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact]], and the posters were ready to be placed up within 24 hours of the outbreak of war.<ref name="irving"/>
The posters were produced in 11 different sizes, ranging from {{convert|15|xx|10|in|cm}} up to large 48-sheet versions.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 47.</ref> The background colour was either red or blue.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 53.</ref> The lettering was probably hand-drawn by Wallcousins:<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kominek|first1=Lex|title=Keep Calm and Carry On – WWII Posters |url=http://www.typophile.com/node/39466#comment-242245|publisher=Typophile|accessdate=28 September 2014}}</ref><ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 44, 47.</ref> it is similar, but not identical, to [[humanist sans-serif typeface]]s such as [[Gill Sans]] and [[Johnston (typeface)|Johnston]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Keep Calm and Carry On: Fonts|url=http://www.k-type.com/keep-calm-carry-on/|publisher=K-Type|accessdate=28 September 2014}} For distinctive features, see for example the terminals of the "C".</ref>
Almost 2,500,000 copies of ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' were printed between 23 August and 3 September 1939 but the poster was not sanctioned for immediate public display.<ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 49–50.</ref> It was instead decided that copies should remain in "cold storage" for use after serious air raids (with resources transferred to ''Your Courage'' and ''Freedom is in Peril''). Copies of ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' were retained until April 1940, but stocks were then pulped as part of the wider [[Paper Salvage 1939–50|Paper Salvage]] campaign.<ref name="irving"/> A very few copies do appear to have been displayed, but such instances were rare and unauthorised: an October 1940 edition of the ''[[The Yorkshire Post|Yorkshire Post]]'' reports the poster hung in a shop in [[Leeds]];<ref>{{cite news |date=22 October 1940 |title=Ban on Silk Stockings: Should They Have Been Rationed? |newspaper=[[The Yorkshire Post|Yorkshire Post and Leeds Mercury]] |page=4 |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/search/results?basicsearch=%22few%20had%20eyes%20for%20the%20poster%22 |accessdate=17 November 2014}}</ref> while a photograph discovered in 2016 shows it on the wall of a government laboratory in [[Bedfordshire]].<ref>{{cite news |first1=Patrick |last1=Sawer |first2=Paul |last2=Hooley |title=Wartime rebels who broke the ban by displaying keep calm and carry on poster |newspaper=The Telegraph |date=30 October 2016 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/10/29/wartime-rebels-who-broke-the-ban-by-displaying-keep-calm-and-car/ |accessdate=5 October 2018 }}</ref>
The remainder of the [[Ministry of Information (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Information]] publicity campaign was cancelled in October 1939 following criticism of its cost and impact. Many people claimed not to have seen the posters; while those who did see them regarded them as patronising and divisive.<ref>Lewis 2017, pp. 52–57.</ref><ref>{{cite news|authorlink=Nigel Rees |last=Rees |first=Nigel |date=20 July 2011|title=Cheer up, the worst is yet to come|work=[[Today programme]]|publisher=[[BBC Radio 4]]|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9543000/9543352.stm}}</ref> Design historian Susannah Walker regards the campaign as "a resounding failure" and reflective of a misjudgement by upper-class civil servants of the mood of the people.<ref>Walker 2012, pp.6–7.</ref>
===Later developments=== In late May and early June 1941, 14,000,000 copies of a leaflet entitled "Beating the Invader" were distributed with a message from Prime Minister [[Winston Churchill]]. The leaflet begins "If invasion comes..." and exhorts the populace to "Stand Firm" and "Carry On". The two phrases do not appear in one sentence, as they applied to different segments of the population depending on their circumstances, with those civilians finding themselves in areas of fighting ordered to stand firm (i.e., stay put) and those not in areas of fighting ordered to carry on (i.e., continue vital war work). Each mandate is identified as a "great order and duty" should invasion come. The leaflet then lists 14 questions and answers on practical measures to be taken.<ref>{{cite news|title=If Invasion Comes. Mr. Churchill's Orders. "Stand Firm and Carry On."|url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47326422|work=The West Australian|date=26 May 1941|location=Perth, WA, Australia|page=6}}</ref>
===Rediscovery and commercialisation=== [[File:Keep Calm And Carry On - Original poster - Barter Books - 17-Oct-2011.jpg|thumb|left|upright|The poster discovered at Barter Books]] [[File:Keep Calm merchandise.jpg|thumb|right|2013 shop display of "Keep Calm" merchandise, including the original slogan and variants such as "Keep Calm and Drink Tea".]] In 2000, Stuart Manley, co-owner with his wife Mary of [[Barter Books]] Ltd. in [[Alnwick]], Northumberland, was sorting through a box of used books bought at auction when he uncovered one of the original "Keep Calm and Carry On" posters. The couple framed it and hung it up by the cash register; it attracted so much interest that Manley began to produce and sell copies.<ref name="Rediscovery">{{cite web |url=http://www.keepcalmhome.com/about.htm |title=About Keep Calm and Carry On}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/profiles/first-person-i-am-the-keep-calm-and-carry-on-man-1672398.html |first=Stuart |last=Manley |title=First person: 'I am the Keep Calm and Carry On man' |newspaper=The Independent |date=25 April 2009 |accessdate=20 August 2018 }}</ref> In late 2005, ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' journalist Susie Steiner featured the replica posters as a Christmas gift suggestion, raising their profile still further.<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 64.</ref> Other companies followed the Manleys' example, and the design rapidly began to be used as the theme for a wide range of products.<ref name=feud>{{cite news |title=Keep Calm and carry on ... into a feud |url= http://www.smh.com.au/world/keep-calm-and-carry-on--into-a-feud-20130503-2ix55.html |accessdate= 4 May 2013 |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date= 4 May 2013}}</ref> Mary Manley later commented, "I didn't want it trivialised; but of course now it's been trivialised beyond belief."<ref name=feud/>
In early 2012, Barter Books debuted an informational short film, ''The Story of Keep Calm and Carry On'', providing visual insight into the modernisation and commercialisation of the design and the phrase.<ref>{{YouTube|id=FrHkKXFRbCI|title=The Story of Keep Calm and Carry On}}</ref>
The poster has become an evocation of British stoicism: the "[[stiff upper lip]]", self-discipline, fortitude and remaining calm in adversity. Susannah Walker comments that it is now seen "not only as a distillation of a crucial moment in Britishness, but also as an inspiring message from the past to the present in a time of crisis".<ref name="Walker"/> She goes on to point out, however, that such an interpretation overlooks the circumstances of its production, and the relative failure of the campaign of which it formed a part.<ref name="Walker">Walker 2012, p. 45.</ref>

web|url=http://www.keepcalmandcarryon.com |title=Keep Calm and Carry On Ltd |publisher=Keepcalmandcarryon.com |accessdate=24 February 2014}}</ref> (managed by entrepreneur Mark Coop) had registered the slogan as a [[community trade mark]] in the EU, CTM No: 009455619, and in the United States, No. 4066622,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theawl.com/2011/10/keep-calm-and-carry-on-trademark-fight|title=The Vicious Trademark Battle Over 'Keep Calm and Carry On'|date=5 October 2011|publisher=[[The Awl]] |first=Maria |last=Bustillos |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160301012125/http://www.theawl.com/2011/10/keep-calm-and-carry-on-trademark-fight |archivedate=1 March 2016}}</ref><ref blog}}</ref> after failing to obtain its registration as a trademark in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Rayner">{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/8785585/Battle-rages-over-Keep-Calm-and-Carry-On-souvenirs.html |location=London |work=The Daily Telegraph |first=Gordon |last=Rayner |title=Battle rages over 'Keep Calm and Carry On' souvenirs | date=24 September 2011}}</ref><ref name="lew74">Lewis 2017, pp. 74–5.</ref> The company issued a take-down request against a seller of ''Keep Calm and Carry On'' products.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-15014748|title=Battle over trademark of 'keep calm' phrase|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=22 September 2010|accessdate=22 September |url=http://www.justanswer.com/uk-law/5e2l0-keep-calm-carry-items-removed.html}}</ref> The company's right to claim the trademark was questioned by, among others, the Manleys of Barter Books, as the slogan had been widely used before registration and was not recognisable as indicating trade origin.<ref name="Phillips"/><ref name="lew74"/> An application was submitted by British intellectual property advisor and UK trademarking service Trade Mark Direct to cancel the registration on the grounds that the words were too widely used for one person to own the exclusive rights,<ref>{{cite Canadian Trade-mark Data |publisher= IC.GC.CA |date= 13 October 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Stay Alive and Avoid Zombies.png|thumb|left|upright|A 2009 parody of the poster]] [[File:Cyber Candy Birmingham after riots.jpg|thumb|right|upright|"Keep Calm and Candy On" painted on boards covering smashed windows of a [[Confectionery store|sweet shop]] in Birmingham during the [[2011 England riots]]]]
==Imitations== As the popularity of the poster in various media has grown, innumerable parodies, imitations and co-optations have also appeared, making it a notable [[Internet meme|meme]]. Messages range from the cute to the overtly political, typically with references to other aspects of popular culture raging from [[Land Rover]] and [[Disney]] to [[Star Wars]] and [[Thomas the Tank Engine]]. Examples have included "Now Panic and Freak Out" (with an upside-down crown), "Get Excited and Make Things" (with a crown incorporating [[wrench|spanners]]), "Keep Calm and Have a Cupcake" (with a [[cupcake]] icon), "Don't Panic and Fake a British Accent", "Keep Spending and Carry On Shopping",<ref name="NYT mag story">{{cite news |last=Walker|first=Rob|authorlink=Rob Walker (journalist) |title=Remixed Messages |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/05/magazine/05FOB-consumed-t.html?_r=2&ref=magazine |work=[[The New York Times Magazine]] |date=5 July 2009 |accessdate= 21 March 2012}}</ref> "Keep Calm and Don't Sneeze" during the [[2009 flu pandemic in the United Kingdom|2009 swine flu pandemic]],<ref>Lewis 2017, p. 66.</ref> "Keep Calm and Call Batman" (with the Batman logo),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://batman-news.com/2013/07/09/new-batman-easter-egg-from-man-of-steel-revealed|title=New Batman Easter egg from 'Man of Steel' revealed|author=Chris Begley |date=9 July 2013 |website=batman-news.com |access-date=13 February 2017}}</ref> and "Keep Calm and Switch to Linux" (with [[Tux (mascot)|Tux]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=Keep calm and switch to Linux |url=http://th03.deviantart.net/fs71/PRE/i/2011/265/2/a/keep_calm_and_switch_to_linux_by_devianteles-d4am5ur.png}}</ref> In March–April 2012, the British pop-rock band [[McFly]] undertook a theatre tour entitled "[[The Keep Calm & Play Louder Tour|The Keep Calm and Play Louder Tour]]", promoted with a poster closely based on that of 1939. In late 2012 and early 2013, the "Save Lewisham Hospital" campaign (a protest against proposed cuts in services at [[University Hospital Lewisham]]) made widespread use of a poster with the slogan "Don't Keep Calm Get Angry and Save Lewisham A&E".<ref>{{cite news |last=Little |first=Mandy |title=Protestors show unity |newspaper=South London Press |location=London |date=21 December 2012 |accessdate=27 January 2013 |url=http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/News.cfm?id=44283&headline=Protestors%20show%20unity |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928023806/http://www.southlondon-today.co.uk/News.cfm?id=44283&headline=Protestors%20show%20unity |archive-date=28 September 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |year=2013 |publisher=Save Lewisham Hospital campaign |url=http://www.savelewishamhospital.com/ |title=Save Lewisham Hospital! |accessdate=27 January 2013}}</ref> The efforts of [[Naheed Nenshi]], mayor of [[Calgary]], Alberta, Canada, to encourage and motivate his citizens in the wake of the [[2013 Alberta floods]] made him the subject of parody "Keep Calm and Nenshi On" fundraising T-shirts.<ref>{{cite news|author=Dean Bennett |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/national/mayor-nenshi-has-captured-calgarys-heart-but-the-worst-at-least-politically-is-yet-to-come/article12884159/ |title=Mayor Nenshi has captured Calgary's heart, but the worst, at least politically, is yet to come |work=The Globe and Mail |date=28 June 2013 |accessdate=24 February 2014 |location=Toronto}}</ref>
